revision.text:
[[File:RCA 7JP4 Electrostatic Picture Tube Front View (late 1940).jpg|thumbnail|Front View of 7JP4 Electrostatic Television Picture Tube]] The '''7JP4''' is an early black and white or monochrome [[cathode ray tube]] (also called picture tube and [[kinescope]]). It was a popular type used in late 1940s low cost and small table model [[televisions]]. The 7JP4 has a 7" diameter round screen which was often partially masked. Unlike later [[electromagnet]]ically deflected TV tubes, the 7JP4 is [[electrostatic]]ally deflected like an oscilloscope tube.
== Development ==
[[File:7JP4 Electrostatic Picture Tube Side View (late 1940).jpg|thumbnail|Side View of 7JP4]] The 7JP4 is part of the 7JPx series of circular face [[cathode ray tubes|electrostatic cathode ray tubes]] (CRT). Originally developed for radar applications as a display device for [[Radar display|radar display A scopes]] around 1944.<ref>{{cite book|last=7JP4|title=Tentative Data from Tung Sol Tube Manual|year=1944|publisher=Tung Sol Lamp Works}}</ref> After World War 2 the CRT was adapted for television applications. There are three versions. The 7JP4 (P4 represents the phosphor that glows white and has medium persistence) for television. For oscilloscope applications the 7JP1 was used (P1 phosphor has a green trace and short persistence). Radar applications the 7JP7 was used (P7 phosphor has a blue-white trace with a long persistence). This CRT was produced by multiple manufacturers ([[RCA]], [[General Electric]], [[Sylvania Electric Products]] and [[Tung-Sol|Tung-sol]]). Except for the type of phosphor used all three are identical in operation and connection. The screen diagonal is 7 inches (17.8 cm) for 7JP1 and 7JP4, but only 5.5 inches (14 cm) for the 7JP7.<ref>{{cite book|last=7JP4|title=Sylvania Engineering Data Service|year=1953|publisher=Sylvania Electric Products Inc.}}</ref>
== 7JP4 Electrical Characteristics == [[File:7JP1, 7JP4 and 7JP7 Pin Out ID and Alignment.jpg|thumbnail|PIN IDENTIFICATION AND ALIGNMENT]] Some General Electrical Characteristics are shown below. Second Anode + Grid 2 (Pin 9) and Plates (Pin 10 & 11 and Pin 7 & 8) have a maximum value limit of 6000 volts dc. Internal arcing can be expected when this voltage is exceeded. Actual values are typically in the 4000 to 5500 volt range, and some sets were operated as low as 2000 volts dc. Grid 1 (Pin 3) can receive either a Negative Bias or a Positive Bias. Pin-2 is the brightness voltage, and pin-3 is the video signal which rides on top of DC, and pin-2 is a DC Level which varies with the Brightness Control. Some sets are backwards and have pin-3 on ground and video on pin-2 along with brightness adjustment. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Parameter !! Value |- | Heater Voltage (Pin 1 and 14) || 6.3 Volts |- | Heater Current || 0.6 Ampere |- | Plates (Pin 10 & 11 and Pin 7 & 8) || 6000 Volts dc MAX |- | Cathode K (Pin 2)|| 120 Volts dc |- | First Anode <Focus> (Pin 5)|| 2800 Volts dc |- | Second Anode + Grid 2 (Pin 9)|| 6000 Volts dc MAX |- | Grid 1 Negative Bias (Pin 3) || 200 Volts dc |- | Grid 1 Positive Bias (Pin 3) || 0 Volts dc |- | Grid 1 Positive Peak (Pin 3) || 2 Volts |- | Vertical Plate Deflection (Pin 10 & 11)|| 216 Volts dc / inch (2.54 cm) |- | Horizontal Plate Deflection (Pin 7 & 8) || 177 Volts dc / inch (2.54 cm) |}
== Early Television in the United States == [[File:Airline 84GSE3011A Electrostatic TV (1950) using 7JP4 Picture Tube.jpg|thumbnail|Example of a picture from an electrostatic television using a 7JP4. The television is a Montgomery Ward Airline 84GSE3011A (made by Sentinel Radio and Television Corp.)]] From 1946 to 1951 the 7JP4 was a common CRT (Picture Tube or [[Kinescope]]) used in lower priced televisions sold in the United States. These television were popular for portable carry around and small table top sets. These smaller sets were direct view electrostatic deflection designs. This required an extremely large amount of voltage to produce an image across the full display screen. In 1946, RCA influenced manufacturers (with royalty free circuit designs) to move toward electromagnetic deflection type televisions. Electromagnetic deflection uses varying magnetic fields to produce a full screen image. Horizontal and vertical electromagnets are placed at the picture tube neck, called the "yoke". This method allowed the image to be viewed on larger screens. The first heavily mass-produced large picture tube to use this newer method of deflection was RCA's 10BP4, introduced in 1946. Soon after electrostatic picture tubes and the television electronic design would be completely replaced.
For a detailed look at US electrostatic TV design and the 7JP4 [[Kinescope]] from an Australian view (by [https://web.archive.org/web/20100824071339/http://cool386.tripod.com/400tv/400tv.html cablehack]) go to the external link below involving the Wards Airline TV (Sentinel model 400TV).<ref>{{cite web|last=cablehack|title=Airline 7" Portable TV|url=http://cool386.tripod.com/400tv/400tv.html|publisher=cool386.tripod.com|accessdate=2013-04-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824071339/http://cool386.tripod.com/400tv/400tv.html|archive-date=2010-08-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Restoration of Dead Technology == The interest in the 7JPx series of CRT's is in restoration of dead technology. Dead Technology represent products that are no longer mass-produced or seriously used. The technology used in these designs have reach their highest level or have been replaced by a better technology.<ref>{{cite web|last=CNET|title=Larry's Museum of Dead Technology|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-19882_3-57337817-250/larrys-museum-of-dead-technology/|publisher=CNET|accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Eng|first=John|title=John Eng's Dead Tech Rescue|url=https://sites.google.com/site/johnengsdeadtechrescue/|publisher=John Eng|accessdate=2013-01-26}}</ref> The restoration of early US made television sets has spurred interest in the 7JP4. Since this particular model is no longer made, only available ones are from old stock or from television sets that cannot be restored. This makes the price of a working CRT very expensive.
Because it is electrostatically deflected and was obsolete by the mid-1950s, most CRT testers will not test the 7JP4 and thus it is best tested in a working TV set. The Precision CR30, Sencore CR-70 and Jackson 707 are some of the CRT testers that are capable of testing the 7JP4,3KP4 and other electrostatic deflection CRTs. Since the availability of these CRT testers is very limited, the prices for such testers are steep, so many restorers test these CRT's on a working TV set that used electrostatic CRTs. There are many picture tube restoring equipment available for magnetic deflection tubes but there is no way to restore electrostatic tubes. The biggest problem with many picture tubes is the loss of emission or electron production due to contaminated or damaged cathode that surrounds the heater.
----
{| class="wikitable" |- ! The 7JP4 was used in the following sets (incomplete list): |- | [[Motorola VT-71]] |- | Motorola VT-73 |- | Hallicrafters 505 |- | Sentinel TV-400 |- | Sentinel TV-405 |- | National TV-7W |- | Philco 50-T701 & 50-T702 |- | Tele-Tone TV-149 |}
These and other early television sets can be found in the "Collectors Guide to Vintage Televisions- Identification and Values", by Bryan Durbal and Glenn Bubenheimer ({{ISBN|1-57432-126-9}}) published by Collector Books, Paducah, KY, USA.<ref>{{cite book|last=Durbal|first=Bryan|title=Collector's Guide to Vintage Televisions|year=1999|publisher=Collector Books|location=Paducah, KY, USA|isbn=1-57432-126-9}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071006124806/http://tubedata.tigahost.com/tubedata/sheets/137/7/7JP4.pdf Datasheet] * [http://www.antiqueradio.org/televisions.htm Phil's Old Radios TV gallery] * Full discussion of electrostatic TV design from an Australian perspective go to [https://web.archive.org/web/20100824071339/http://cool386.tripod.com/400tv/400tv.html Sentinel 400TV]
[[Category:Vacuum tube displays]] [[Category:History of television]]

<!-- Please leave this line alone! --> {{Infobox Airliner accident|name=Aeroméxico Flight 230 | image= Aeromexico Flight 230 after running off the runway in Chihuahua.gif | Image caption= Flight 230 in flames after running off the runway. | Date=27 July 1981 | Type=Slid off runway in bad weather | occurrence_type=Runway overrun | Site=[[Chihuahua International Airport|General Roberto Fierro Villalobos International Airport]], [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua|Chihuahua]], [[Mexico]] | Passengers=60 | Crew=6 | Survivors=34 | Fatalities=32 (30 passengers, 2 crew) | Injuries=34 | Aircraft Type=[[McDonnell Douglas DC-9|McDonnell Douglas DC-9-32]] | Origin=[[General Mariano Escobedo International Airport|Monterey-General Mariano Escobedo International Airport]] | Destination=[[General Roberto Fierro Villalobos International Airport|Chihuahua International Airport]] | Operator=[[Aeromexico]] | Tail Number=[http://www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?regsearch=XA-DEN&distinct_entry=true XA-DEN] | Ship name= ''Yucatan''
}} '''Aeroméxico Flight 230''' experienced a hard landing at Chihuahua Airport on July 27, 1981. Thirty-two people were killed when the [[McDonnell Douglas DC-9|McDonnell Douglas DC-9-32]] jet aircraft was heavily damaged by impact with the ground and fire on approach in high winds.
== Accident sequence == [[File:Aero Mexico DC-9 XA-DEN 01.jpg|thumb|left|XA-DEN, the aircraft involved in the accident, pictured in 1974 at Los Angeles International Airport]] The flight was uneventful until landing at [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua|Chihuahua]]. There were isolated [[cumulonimbus]] clouds with strong [[squalls]] and showers during approach and landing. Upon [[touchdown]], the aircraft bounced once and struck the ground; the aircraft then slid off the [[runway]], broke up and caught on fire. Thirty-four passengers and crew were able to flee the wreckage; the smoke and fire caused the deaths of those that remained trapped.<ref>[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19810727-0 ASN Aircraft accident McDonnell Douglas DC-9-32 XA-DEN Chihuahua Airport (CUU)]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/dnetGOjg/270781.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314013011/http://dnausers.d-n-a.net/dnetGOjg/270781.htm |archivedate=2012-03-14 |df= }}</ref>
== See also == *[[Swissair Flight 316]] another fatal aviation crash where an aircraft overran the runway.

page.title: Angular Correlation of Electron Positron Annihilation Radiation

revision.text:
{{Condensed matter experiments}}
'''Angular Correlation of Electron Positron Annihilation Radiation (ACAR or ACPAR)''' is a technique of solid state physics to investigate the [[electronic structure]] of metals. It uses [[positrons]] which are implanted into a sample and [[annihilation|annihilate]] with the electrons. In the majority of annihilation events, two [[Gamma quantum|gamma quanta]] are created that are, in the [[Frame of reference|reference frame]] of the electron-positron pair, emitted in exactly opposite directions. In the laboratory frame, there is a small angular deviation from collinearity, which is caused by the [[momentum]] of the electron. Hence, measuring the angular correlation of the annihilation radiation yields information about the momentum distribution of the electrons in the solid.
==Investigation of the electronic structure==
[[File:Fermi surface of Copper measured with 2D ACAR.jpg|thumb|Fermi surface and electron momentum density of Copper in the reduced zone schema measured with 2D ACAR.<ref name=Weber2013>{{Cite journal|last=Weber|first=J. A.|last2=Böni|first2=P.|last3=Ceeh|first3=H.|last4=Leitner|first4=M.|last5=Hugenschmidt|first5=Ch|date=2013-01-01|title=First 2D-ACAR Measurements on Cu with the new Spectrometer at TUM|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1742-6596/443/i=1/a=012092|journal=Journal of Physics: Conference Series|language=en|volume=443|issue=1|pages=012092|doi=10.1088/1742-6596/443/1/012092|issn=1742-6596|arxiv=1304.5363}}</ref>]] All the macroscopic electronic and magnetic properties of a solid result from its microscopic electronic structure. In the simple [[free electron model]], the electrons do not interact with each other nor with the atomic cores. The relation between energy <math>E</math> and momentum <math>p</math> is given by :<math>E=\frac{p^2}{2 m}</math> with the electron mass <math>m</math>. Hence, there is an unambiguous connection between electron energy and momentum. Because of the [[Pauli exclusion principle]] the electrons fill all the states up to a maximum energy, the so-called [[Fermi energy]]. By the momentum-energy relation, this corresponds to the Fermi momentum <math>p_F</math>. The border between occupied and unoccupied momentum states, the [[Fermi surface]], is arguably the most significant feature of the electronic structure and has a strong influence on the solid's properties.<ref name=Dugdale>{{Cite journal|last=Dugdale|first=S. B.|date=2016-01-01|title=Life on the edge: a beginner’s guide to the Fermi surface|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1402-4896/91/i=5/a=053009|journal=Physica Scripta|language=en|volume=91|issue=5|pages=053009|doi=10.1088/0031-8949/91/5/053009|issn=1402-4896|bibcode=2016PhyS...91e3009D}}</ref> In the free electron model, the Fermi surface is a sphere.
With ACAR it is possible to measure the momentum distribution of the electrons. A measurement on a free electron gas for example would give a positive intensity for momenta <math>p<p_F</math> and zero intensity for <math>p>p_F</math>. The Fermi surface itself can easily be identified from such a measurement by the discontinuity at <math>p_F</math>.
[[File:Electron momentum density in the extended zone scheme.svg|frame|Example of a 1D electron momentum density measured by an ACAR measurement. Bands crossing the Fermi level give discontinuities (green) which are superimposed on a continuous distribution from completely filled bands (orange).]]
In reality, there ''is'' interaction between the electrons with each other and the atomic cores of the crystal. This has several consequences: For example, the unambiguous relation between energy and momentum of an electronic state is broken and an [[electronic band structure]] is formed. Measuring the momentum of one electronic state gives a distribution of momenta which are all separated by [[reciprocal lattice]] vectors. Hence, an ACAR measurement on a solid with completely filled bands (i.e. on an [[Insulator (electricity)|insulator]]) gives a continuous distribution. An ACAR measurement on a metal has discontinuities where bands cross the Fermi level in all [[Brillouin zone]]s in reciprocal space. This discontinuous distribution is superimposed by a continuous distribution from the entirely filled bands. From the discontinuities the Fermi surface can be extracted.
Since positrons that are created by [[beta decay]] possess a longitudinal spin polarization it is possible to investigate the spin-resolved electronic structure of magnetic materials. In this way, contributions from the majority and minority spin channel can be separated and the Fermi surface in the respective spin channels can be measured.<ref name=magAcar>{{Cite journal|last=Weber|first=J. A.|date=2015-01-01|title=Spin-Resolved Fermi Surface of the Localized Ferromagnetic Heusler Compound|url=http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.206404|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=115|issue=20|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.206404|bibcode=2015PhRvL.115t6404W|pmid=26613459|page=206404|arxiv=1510.07808}}</ref>
ACAR has several advantages and disadvantages compared to other, more well known techniques for the investigation of the electronic structure like [[ARPES]] and [[Quantum oscillations (experimental technique)|quantum oscillation]]: ACAR requires neither low temperatures, high magnetic fields or [[Ultra-high vacuum|UHV]] conditions. Furthermore, it is possible to probe the electronic structure at the surface and in the bulk (<math>\approx</math> {{val|100|u=[[Nanometer|nm]]}} deep). However, ACAR is reliant on defect free samples as vacancy concentrations of up to {{val|e=-6}} per atom can efficiently trap positrons and distort the measurement.<ref group=note>This sensitivity is used in [[Positron Lifetime Spectroscopy|positron lifetime spectroscopy]] to investigate even very low defect concentrations.</ref>
==Theory==
In an ACAR measurement the angular deviation of many pairs of annihilation radiation is measured. Therefore, the underlying physical observable is often called ‘two photon momentum density’ (TPMD) or <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math>. Quantum mechanically, <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> can be expressed as the squared absolute value of the [[Fourier transform]] of the multi-particle [[wave function]] <math>\Psi^{ep}(\mathbf{r})</math> of all the electron and the positron in the solid: :<math> \rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})=\left| \int d\mathbf{r} e^{-i2\pi\mathbf{rp}} \Psi^{ep}(\mathbf{r}) \right|^2 </math> As it is not possible to imagine or compute the multi-particle wave function <math>\Psi^{ep}(\mathbf{r})</math>, it is often written as the sum of the single particle wave functions of the electron <math>\Psi_{\mathbf{k},j}^e(\mathbf{r})</math> in the <math>\mathbf{k}</math>th state in the <math>j</math>th band and the positron wave function <math>\Psi^p(\mathbf{r})</math>: :<math> \rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})=\sum_j\sum_{\mathbf{k}=\mathrm{occ.}} \left| \int d\mathbf{r} e^{-i2\pi\mathbf{rp}} \Psi^{e}_{\mathbf{k},j}(\mathbf{r})\Psi^{p}(\mathbf{r}) \sqrt{\gamma(\mathbf{r})} \right|^2 </math> The enhancement factor <math>\gamma(\mathbf{r})</math> accounts for the electron-positron correlation.<ref group=note>For simplicity the electron-electron correlation is ignored in this example.</ref> There exist sophisticated enhancement models to describe the electron-positron correlations,<ref name=Jarlborg1987>{{cite journal|title=Local-density approach for calculation of electron-positron enhancement in transition metals|last=Jarlborg|first=T.|last2=Singh|first2= A. K.|journal=Phys. Rev. B|date= 1987-01-09|page=4660|volume=36|issue=9|bibcode=1987PhRvB..36.4660J|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.36.4660}}</ref> but in the following it will be assumed that <math>\gamma=1</math>. This approximation is called the independent particle model (IPM).
A very illustrative form of the TPMD can be obtained by the use of the Fourier coefficients for the wave function product <math> \Psi^{e}_{\mathbf{k},j}(\mathbf{r})\Psi^{p}(\mathbf{r})</math>: :<math>C_{\mathbf{G},j}(\mathbf{k})=\int \int d\mathbf{r} e^{-i2\pi\mathbf{r(k+G)}} \Psi^{e}_{\mathbf{k},j}(\mathbf{r})\Psi^{p}(\mathbf{r}) </math> These Fourier coefficients are distributed over all reciprocal vectors <math>\mathbf{G}</math>. If one assumes that the overlap of the electron and the positron wave function is constant for the same band <math>j</math>, summing <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> over all reciprocal lattice vectors gives a very instructive result:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lock|first=D. G.|last2=Crisp|first2=V. H. C.|last3=West|first3=R. N.|date=1973-01-01|title=Positron annihilation and Fermi surface studies: a new approach|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0305-4608/3/i=3/a=014|journal=Journal of Physics F: Metal Physics|language=en|volume=3|issue=3|pages=561|doi=10.1088/0305-4608/3/3/014|issn=0305-4608|bibcode=1973JPhF....3..561L}}</ref> :<math> \Rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{k})=\sum_{\mathbf{G}} \rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{G+k})=\sum_j\sum_{\mathbf{k}=\mathrm{occ.}} \left|C_{\mathbf{G},j}(\mathbf{k})\right|^2=\sum_j A_j \Theta(\mathbf{k}_F-\mathbf{k}) </math> The function <math>\Theta(\mathbf{k})</math> is the [[Heaviside step function]] and the constant <math>A_j=\sum_\mathbf{G} \left|C_{\mathbf{G},j}(\mathbf{k})\right|^2 </math> . This means, if <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> is folded back into the first Brillouin zone, the resulting density is flat except at the Fermi momentum. Therefore, the Fermi surface can be easily identified by looking for this discontinuities in <math>\Rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{k})</math>.
==Experimental details==
[[File:Momentum wiki.svg|frame|When an electron and a positron annihilate, the annihilation radiation conserves the momentum of the initial electron by a Doppler shift and an angular deviation from collinearity.]]
When a positron is implanted into a solid it will quickly lose all its kinetic energy and annihilate with an electron. By this process two gamma quanta with {{val|511|u=keV}} each are created which are in the reference frame of the electron positron pair emitted in exactly anti-parallel directions. In the laboratory frame, however, there is a [[Doppler shift]] from {{val|511|u=keV}} and an angular deviation from collinearity. Although the full momentum information about the momentum of the electron is encoded in the annihilation radiation, due to technical limitations it cannot be fully recovered. Either one measures the [[Doppler broadening]] of the {{val|511|u=keV}} annihilation radiation (DBAR) or the angular correlation of the annihilation radiation (ACAR).
For DBAR a detector with a high energy resolution like a high purity [[Semiconductor detector|germanium detector]] is needed. Such detectors typically do not resolve the position of absorbed photons. Hence only the longitudinal component of the electron momentum <math>p_\parallel</math> can be measured. The resulting measurement is a 1D projection of <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math>.
In ACAR position sensitive detectors, [[gamma camera]]s or [[Wire chamber|multi wire proportional chambers]], are used. Such detectors have a position resolution of typically {{val|1|to|3|u=mm}} but an energy resolution which is just good enough to sort out scattered photons or background radiation. As <math>p_\parallel</math> is discarded, a 2D projection of <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> is measured. In order to get a high angular resolution of {{val|1e-3|u=rad}} and better, the detectors have to be set up at distances between {{val|16|to|20|u=m}} from each other. Although it is possible to get even better angular resolutions by placing the detectors further apart, this comes at cost of the counting rate. Already with moderate detector distances, the measurement of one projection of <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> typically takes weeks.{{refn|group=note|Further details about an ACAR setup can be found in <ref name=Ceeh>{{Cite journal|last=Ceeh|first=Hubert|last2=Weber|first2=J. A.|last3=Leitner|first3=Michael|last4=Böni|first4=Peter|last5=Hugenschmidt|first5=Christoph|date=2013-04-01|title=The source-sample stage of the new two-dimensional angular correlation of annihilation radiation spectrometer at Technische Universität München|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/rsi/84/4/10.1063/1.4801454|journal=Review of Scientific Instruments|volume=84|issue=4|pages=043905|doi=10.1063/1.4801454|issn=0034-6748|bibcode=2013RScI...84d3905C}}</ref>}}
As ACAR measures projections of the TPMD it is necessary to reconstruct <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math> in order to recover the Fermi surface. For such a reconstruction similar techniques as for X-ray [[computed tomography]] are used. In contrast to a human body, a crystal has many symmetries which can be included into the reconstruction. This makes the procedure more complex but increases the quality of the reconstruction. Another way to evaluate ACAR spectra is by a quantitative comparison with [[ab initio calculations]].<ref name=Ceeh2016>{{Cite journal|last=Ceeh|first=Hubert|first9=Dieter|date=2016-02-16|title=Local electron-electron interaction strength in ferromagnetic nickel determined by spin-polarized positron annihilation|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/srep20898|journal=Scientific Reports|language=en|volume=6|doi=10.1038/srep20898|issn=2045-2322|pmc=4754699|pmid=26879249|pages=20898|arxiv=1501.02584|bibcode=2016NatSR...620898C}}</ref>
==History== In the early years, ACAR was mainly used to investigate the physics of the electron-positron annihilation process. In the 1930s several annihilation mechanism were discussed.<ref name=Fermi>{{Cite journal|last=Fermi|first=Enrico|last2=Uhlenbeck|first2=George|date=1933-01-01|title=On the Recombination of Electrons and Positrons|url=http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRev.44.510.2|journal=Physical Review|volume=44|issue=6|pages=510–511|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.44.510.2|bibcode=1933PhRv...44..510F}}</ref><ref name=Klemperer>{{Cite journal|last=Klemperer|first=Otto|date=1934-07-01|title=On the annihilation radiation of the positron|url=http://www.journals.cambridge.org/abstract_S0305004100012536|journal=Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society|volume=30|issue=03|doi=10.1017/s0305004100012536|issn=1469-8064|bibcode=1934PCPS...30..347K}}</ref><ref name=Perrin>{{Cite journal|last=Perrin|first=F.|date=1933|title=Materialisation d'electrons lors du choc de deuxelectrons. Processus divers d'annihilation deselectrons positifs|journal=Comptes Rendus de l'Académie des Sciences|volume=197|page=1302}}</ref> [[Otto Klemperer (physicist)|Otto Klemperer]] could show with his angular correlation setup that the electron-positron pairs annihilate mainly into two gamma quanta which are emitted anti-parallel.<ref name=Klemperer/> In the 1950s, it was realized that by measuring the deviation from collinearity of the annihilation radiation information about the electronic structure of a solid can be obtained.<ref name=DeBenedetti>{{cite journal|last=DeBenedetti|first=S.|last2=Cowan|first2=C. E.|last3=Konneker|first3=W. R.|last4=Primakoff|first4=H.|date=1950-01-01|title=On the Angular Distribution of Two-Photon Annihilation Radiation|url=http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRev.77.205|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.77.205|journal=Phys. Rev.|volume=77|page=205|bibcode=1950PhRv...77..205D}}</ref><ref name=MaierLeibnitz>{{cite journal|last=Maier-Leibnitz|first=Heinz|date=1951|title=Impuls bei der Vernichtung langsamer Positronen in verschiedenen festen Stoffen|journal=Zeitschrift für Naturforschung A|volume=6|page=663|bibcode=1951ZNatA...6..663M|doi=10.1515/zna-1951-1117}}</ref>
During this time mainly setups with ‘long slit geometry’ were used. They consisted of a positron source and a sample in the center, one fixed detector on one side and a second movable detector on the other side of the sample. Each detector was collimated in such a way that the active area was much smaller in one than in the other dimension (thus ‘long slit’).{{refn|group=note|For a sketch of a long slit setup see for example<ref name=Fujiwara>{{cite journal|last=Fujiwara|first=Kunio|first2=Osamu|last2=Sueoka|date=1966-01-07|journal=JPSJ|title=A Precise Measurement of the Angular Correlation of Annihilation Radiation in Copper Single Crystals|volume=21|page=1947|url=http://jpsj.ipap.jp/link?JPSJ/21/1947/|doi=10.1143/JPSJ.21.1947|bibcode=1966JPSJ...21.1947F}}</ref>}} A measurement with a long slit setup yields a 1D projection of the electron momentum density <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math>. Hence, this technique is called 1D-ACAR.
The development of two-dimensional [[gamma camera]]s and [[Wire chamber|multi wire proportional chambers]] in the 1970s and early 1980s led to the setting up of the first 2D-ACAR spectrometer.<ref name=Manuel>{{Cite journal|last=Manuel|first=A. A.|last2=Fischer|first2=Ø.|last3=Peter|first3=M.|last4=Jeavons|first4=A. P.|date=1978-10-15|title=An application of proportional chambers to the measurement of the electronic properties of solids by positron annihilation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0029554X78906936|journal=Nuclear Instruments and Methods|volume=156|issue=1|pages=67–71|doi=10.1016/0029-554X(78)90693-6|bibcode=1978NucIM.156...67M}}</ref><ref name=West1981>{{Cite journal|last=West|first=R. N.|date=1981|title=A high-efficiency two-dimensional angular correlation spectrometer for positron studies|url=http://stacks.iop.org/0022-3735/14/i=4/a=021|journal=Journal of Physics E: Scientific Instruments|volume=14|issue=4|doi=10.1088/0022-3735/14/4/021|pmid=|access-date=|via=|bibcode=1981JPhE...14..478W}}</ref> This was an improvement to 1D-ACAR in two ways: i) The detection efficiency could be improved and ii) the informational content was greatly increased as the measurement gave a 2D projection of <math>\rho^{2\gamma}(\mathbf{p})</math>. An important early example of the use of spin-polarized 2D-ACAR is the proof of [[Half-metal|half metallicity]] in the half-[[Heusler alloy]] NiMnSb.<ref name=Hanssen1986>{{cite journal|last=Hanssen|first=K. E. H. M.|last2=Mijnarends|first2=P. E.|title=Positron-annihilation study of the half-metallic ferromagnet NiMnSb: Theory|journal=Phys. Rev. B|date=1986-01-10|volume=34|issue=8|page=5009|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.34.5009|bibcode=1986PhRvB..34.5009H}}</ref><ref name=Hanssen1990>{{cite journal|last=Hanssen|first=K. E. H. M.|last2=Mijnarends|first2=P. E.|last3=Rabou|first3= L. P. L. M.|last4=Buschow|first4=K. H. J.|title=Positron-annihilation study of the half-metallic ferromagnet NiMnSb: Experiment|journal=Phys. Rev. B|date=1990-01-07|volume=42|issue=3|page=1533|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.42.1533|bibcode=1990PhRvB..42.1533H}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptcd3JbojkMC|title=Positron Spectroscopy of Solids|last=Dupasquier|first=Alfredo|date=1995-01-01|publisher=IOS Press|isbn=9789051992038|language=en}} *{{cite journal|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/ltp/40/4/10.1063/1.4869588|title=Probing the Fermi surface by positron annihilation and Compton scattering|last=Dugdale|first=S. B.|date=2014|journal=Low Temperature Physics|volume=40|issue=4|page=328|doi=10.1063/1.4869588|bibcode=2014LTP....40..328D}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{short description|unwanted secondary product of an item or process}} A '''by-product''' is a secondary product derived from a manufacturing process or chemical reaction. It is not the primary product or service being produced. In the context of [[Manufacturing|production]], a by-product is the 'output from a joint production process that is minor in quantity and/or [[net realizable value]] (NRV) when compared with the main products'.<ref>Wouters, Mark; Selto, Frank H.; Hilton, Ronald W.; Maher, Michael W. (2012): ''Cost Management: Strategies for Business Decisions'', International Edition, McGraw-Hill, p. 535.</ref> Because they are deemed to have no influence on reported financial results, by-products do not receive allocations of [[joint cost]]s. By-products also by convention are not inventoried, but the NRV from by-products is typically recognized as 'other income' or as a reduction of [[joint production process]]ing costs when the by-product is produced.<ref>[[World Trade Organization]] (2004): ''United States - Final dumping determination on softwood lumber from Canada'', WT/DS264/AB/R, 11 August 2004.</ref> A by-product can be useful and marketable or it can be considered waste. For example, [[bran]] is a byproduct of the [[mill (grinding)|milling]] of refined [[flour]], sometimes [[compost]]ed or burned for disposal but in other cases used as a nutritious ingredient in [[food]] or [[animal feed|feed]], and [[gasoline]] was once a byproduct of [[oil refinery|oil refining]] that later became a desirable [[commodity]] as [[motor fuel]].
[[International Energy Agency|IEA]] defines "by-product" in the context of [[life-cycle assessment]]: "... main products, co-products (which involve similar revenues to the main product), by-products (which result in smaller revenues), and waste products (which provide little or no revenue)."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ieabioenergy-task38.org/systemdefining/biomitre_technical_manual.pdf# |title=BIOMITRE Technical Manual, Horne, R. E. and Matthews, R., November 2004 |access-date=2011-02-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726171133/http://www.ieabioenergy-task38.org/systemdefining/biomitre_technical_manual.pdf# |archive-date=2011-07-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
While some chemists treat "by-product" and "side-product" as synonyms in the above sense of a generic secondary (untargeted) product, others find it useful to distinguish the two. When the two terms are distinguished, "by-product" is used to refer to a product that is not desired but inevitably results from molecular fragments of starting materials and/or reagents that are not incorporated into the desired product, as a consequence of conservation of mass. In contrast, "side-product" is used to refer to a product that is formed from a competitive process that could, in principle, be suppressed by optimization of reaction conditions.
== See also == * [[By-product synergy]] * [[Circular economy]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Recycling]] [[Category:Product]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Companhia de Gás de São Paulo
Comgás | logo = Comgás.png | logo_size = 120px | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Sociedade Anônima]] | traded_as = {{BM&F Bovespa|cvm=15636|CGAS3|CGAS5}} | predecessor = | successor = | founder = | defunct = | fate = | area_served = | key_people = Nelson Gomes, ([[CEO]]) | industry = [[Oil and gas industry]] | products = | services = Natural gas distribution | revenue = {{decrease}}[[United States dollar|US$]] 1.6 billion (2017) [http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/mercado/893680-lucro-da-comgas-cai-16-e-fecha-2010-em-r-5799-milhoes.shtml] | operating_income = | net_income = {{decrease}}[[United States dollar|US$]] 193.1 million (2017) | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,210 | parent = [[Cosan]] | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | homepage = {{URL|www.comgas.com.br}} | caption = | foundation = 1872 | location_city = [[São Paulo]] | location_country = [[Brazil]] | location = | locations = }} '''Comgás''' is a Brazilian gas distributor focused on [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo state]]. It is Brazil's biggest gas distributor, with around 1,6 million residential, commercial and industrial customers, as of 2016, who receive gas through about {{convert|14.000|km}} of pipelines. Comgás was founded in 1872. The company had been wholly owned by the São Paulo state-owned power generation utility, ''[[Companhia Energética de São Paulo]]'' until April 1999, when CESP's stake was sold to the British [[BG Group]] and to [[Royal Dutch Shell]]. Comgas sells gas under a 30-year franchise, with a potential for a further 20 years. Brazilian conglomerate [[Cosan]] owns 61.73% of Comgas's stock, and Shell 17.12%. The remainder is publicly traded on [[BM&F Bovespa]]. Cosan acquired its stake from [[BG Group]] in November 2012 for $1.7 billion. {{cite news |url= http://www.rttnews.com/1998637/bg-group-closes-sale-of-comg%C3%A1s-stake-quick-facts.aspx?type=maa |title= BG Group Closes Sale Of Comgás Stake - Quick Facts |work = RTT News |date=2012-11-06 |accessdate=2012-12-03}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Brazil|Companies|Energy}} * [http://www.comgas.com.br The company's home page in Portuguese] {{DEFAULTSORT:Comgas}} [[Category:Companies based in São Paulo]] [[Category:Oil and gas companies of Brazil]] [[Category:Companies listed on the São Paulo Stock Exchange]] {{energy-company-stub}} {{Brazil-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Nor'easter 1969-12-26 weather map.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|[[Surface weather analysis]] of the nor'easter, with its track highlighted in red]]
The '''December 1969 nor'easter''' was a strong winter storm that mainly affected the [[Northeastern United States]] and southern [[Quebec]] between December 25 and December 28, 1969. The multi-faceted storm system included a [[tornado]] outbreak, record snow accumulations, a damaging [[ice storm]], and flooding rains.
The storm developed over [[Texas]] by December 25 and advanced eastward, spawning over a dozen tornadoes in [[Louisiana]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[Florida]]. Upon reaching the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]], the cyclone turned northeastward and intensified into a powerful [[nor'easter]]. On December 26 and 27, the storm's forward movement slowed to a drift, causing very heavy snow over [[Upstate New York]], [[Vermont]], and southern Quebec. Warm onshore winds, caused by a storm track close to the shore, allowed precipitation to change to sleet and rain in central and eastern New England. Where precipitation remained as snow, accumulations reached {{convert|40|in|cm}} or more, crippling travel. Drifts up to {{convert|30|ft|m|abbr=on}} high blocked roadways, isolating some communities and forcing emergency workers to rely on [[snowmobiles]] for transportation. At least 20 fatalities were attributed to the storm in New York and New England.
In central New England, a severe freezing rain event occurred along the boundary between cold air to the west and warmer air to the east. Several inches of [[glaze ice]], accompanied by gale-force winds, caused damage comparable to the aftermath of the [[1938 New England hurricane]]. Throughout the region, the snow and ice—in some cases further weighted by heavy rainfall—caused roofs to cave in. [[Montreal]] received {{convert|27.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow in that city's biggest snowstorm on record at the time; officials blamed the storm for 15 deaths in Quebec. In eastern New England, [[ice jam]]s, poor drainage, and several inches of rain caused flooding that forced people from their homes and submerged roadways. Wind gusts to {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and strong waves battered the coastline.
==Background== The winter of 1969–1970 continued a long-term [[El Niño]] from the previous winter,<ref name="KU473">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 473</ref> which featured two significant storms in the Northeastern United States, including the [[February 1969 nor'easter|"Lindsay storm"]] in February.<ref name="NCDC">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=The Northeast Snowfall Impact Scale (NESIS)|date=|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 7, 2011|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/snow-and-ice/nesis.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110105064938/http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/snow-and-ice/nesis.php|archivedate=2011-01-05}}</ref> [[North Atlantic Oscillation]] (NAO) values ranged from weakly negative to weakly positive in the period leading up to the storm, trending more consistently negative in the days surrounding its genesis. NAO values dropped significantly in the wake of the nor'easter, signaling abnormally cold temperatures during January 1970.<ref name="KU473"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Climate Prediction Center|title=Observation of Monthly Mean North Atlantic Oscillation|year=|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 7, 2010|url=http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/precip/CWlink/pna/month_nao_index.shtml}}</ref> December 1969 was a month of active weather throughout the Northeast, with frequent light to moderate snow events preceding the late-month nor'easter. A significant storm on December 22–23 dropped {{convert|8|to|24|in|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} of snow in eastern New York and northern New England,<ref name="climo"/><ref name="ncdc159"/> as well as significant freezing rain in southern and eastern New England. Many of the same areas would be impacted again just days later.<ref name="ncdc156"/>
Before the cyclone's arrival, a {{convert|1033|hPa|inHg|lk=on|adj=on|abbr=on}} [[high-pressure area]] situated north of [[New England]] funneled very cold air into the region; the {{convert|-22|F|C}} air temperature at [[Albany, New York]], on December 25 still holds the record for the city's coldest December temperature.<ref>{{cite web|author=Northeast Regional Climate Center|title=Minimum 1-day mean min temperature for Albany AP, NY|accessdate=January 9, 2016|url=http://xmacis.rcc-acis.org/|publisher=Cornell University}}</ref> On December 25 and 26, extensive [[cold air damming]] and [[frontogenesis]] occurred along the U.S. East Coast. The high-pressure area slowly retreated as the storm approached.<ref name="KU467">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 467</ref> [[File:December 1969 nor'easter 2.jpg|upright=1.2|thumb|Map of the developing low-pressure system north of the [[Gulf of Mexico]] on December 25]]
==Meteorological history== The nor'easter originated in a weak area of [[low-pressure area|surface low pressure]] that formed over northern Texas by December 25. It moved generally eastward over the next day as it crossed the [[Deep South]].<ref name="KU469">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 469</ref> A southerly [[Low level jet|low-level jet]] (a localized wind stream in the lower levels of the atmosphere) developed by midday over [[Mississippi]] and [[Alabama]], and drifted eastward.<ref name="KU468">Kocin and Uccellini, p. 468</ref> Precipitation soon blossomed, with heavy snow falling over the [[Appalachian Mountains]] by late on December 25. The low turned toward the northeast by early on December 26 to follow the temperature gradient along the East Coast, at which time the storm underwent the first of two periods of rapid intensification. In 12 hours, barometric pressure fell 12 hPa to {{convert|996|hPa|inHg|abbr=on}} while the nor'easter accelerated from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] to the coast of [[New Jersey]].<ref name="KU467"/> This bout of strengthening occurred as the associated upper-level [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] at the 500-millibar level – several miles into the atmosphere – assumed a negative tilt from northwest to southeast.<ref name="KU473"/> Heavy precipitation overspread the Mid-Atlantic and New England early on December 26.<ref name="KU467"/>
The low-level jet continued to strengthen and delivered warm air to areas east of the storm center, where precipitation quickly transitioned to rain. The jet ultimately reached extremely high velocities of {{convert|55|m/s|mph|abbr=on}} as it wrapped around the northern side of the low, feeding abundant moisture into areas of heavy precipitation.<ref name="KU473"/> The storm slowed drastically on December 26,<ref name="KU467"/> and over the next 24 hours, it moved very slowly from [[Cape May, New Jersey]], to near [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]].<ref name="climo"/> During this period, exceptionally heavy snow fell over eastern New York, Vermont, and southern Quebec. While located just east of [[Long Island]] on December 27, the nor'easter began its second phase of rapid strengthening that brought central pressure down to {{convert|976|hPa|inHg|abbr=on}}. During this period of intensification, snow propagated around the western side of the system, reaching as far south as Long Island.<ref name="KU467"/>
With a storm track very close to the shore and a retreating high-pressure area to the northeast, onshore winds allowed temperatures to warm above freezing in eastern and northern New England. A [[weather front|frontal boundary]] between the warm Atlantic air and a residual wedge of colder air over the interior served as the focus for a severe [[ice storm]] in central New England.<ref name="KU467"/> Thunder and lightning accompanied the precipitation in some areas.<ref name="ncdc154"/><ref name="ncdc157"/> By 12:00 UTC on December 27, the attendant upper-level trough matured into a closed [[cold-core low]].<ref name="KU473"/> The nor'easter continued to drift toward the east-northeast over the next 24 hours.<ref name="KU467"/>
==Impact and aftermath== [[File:Christmas 1969 nor'easter snowfall map.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|United States snowfall map from the [[National Climatic Data Center]]]]
===Southeast U.S. and Mid-Atlantic=== The developing extratropical cyclone spawned 16 known tornadoes and waterspouts in [[Louisiana]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[Florida]], becoming the largest [[Christmas Day]] tornado outbreak on record.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ian Livingston|title=Christmas Eve and Christmas Day tornado history|date=December 23, 2012|publisher=US Tornadoes|accessdate=January 8, 2016|url=http://www.ustornadoes.com/2012/12/23/christmas-eve-and-christmas-day-tornado-history/}}</ref> A short-lived [[Fujita scale|F3]] tornado touched down in [[Vermillion Parish, Louisiana]], destroying eight homes near [[Kaplan, Louisiana|Kaplan]] and damaging 25 more. One woman was killed and eight were injured, three severely enough to require hospitalization. Another damaging tornado moved through several settlements in southern [[Iberville Parish, Louisiana|Iberville Parish]] just over two hours later; the tornado destroyed seven homes and damaged multiple other buildings, with one injury reported. The tornado was officially classified an F3,<ref name="ncdc156">''Storm Data'', p. 156</ref> though meteorologist [[Thomas P. Grazulis]] determined it to have caused damage consistent with an F2 rating.<ref name="grazulis502"/> A non-tornadic wind gust destroyed a nearby trailer home.<ref name="ncdc156">''Storm Data'', p. 156</ref> Later that day, a tornado skipped along a path through [[Catahoula Parish, Louisiana|Catahoula]] and [[Concordia Parish, Louisiana|Concordia]] parishes, touching down three different times. The F2 tornado damaged about 20 trailer homes in [[Glade, Louisiana|Glade]], and caused further damage near the end of its track.<ref name="grazulis502">Grazulis, p. 502</ref>
A tornado in southern Georgia, about {{convert|9|mi|km|abbr=on}} west of [[Albany, Georgia|Albany]],<ref name="grazulis502">Grazulis, p. 502</ref> damaged or destroyed several small homes, killed three head of cattle, toppled numerous trees, and injured seven people. Elsewhere in the state, there were isolated reports of hail and damaging thunderstorm winds.<ref name="ncdc155">''Storm Data'', p. 155</ref> Several tornadoes in the [[Florida Panhandle]] caused minor to moderate damage to trees and homes, the most destructive of them occurring in [[Quincy, Florida]].<ref name="ncdc154-155">''Storm Data'', pp. 154–155</ref> That tornado struck an industrial area and unroofed at least three structures.<ref name="airports">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Snow Piles Quickly in Coast Area|date=December 26, 1969|work=Youngstown Vindicator|accessdate=March 10, 2011|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rEpJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z4QMAAAAIBAJ&dq=maryland%20snow&pg=665%2C3741045}}</ref> A tornado in [[Lee, Florida]], destroyed a trailer, damaged farm buildings, and injured one person.<ref name="ncdc154-155"/>
In addition to widespread rain, parts of northern [[South Carolina]] experienced freezing rain that damaged trees and power lines. Freezing rain and sleet fell over the southern [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] of [[North Carolina]], resulting in power outages and dangerous travel conditions.<ref name="ncdc158-159">''Storm Data'', pp. 158–159</ref> At least one fatal traffic accident was reported. Heavy snow covered the northwest Piedmont and [[Western North Carolina|Mountain Region]] of the state, accumulating to around {{convert|12|in|cm|abbr=on}} at [[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville]];<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=For much of the state, a white Christmas|date=December 26, 1969|newspaper=The Daily Times-News|accessdate=January 9, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4000987/the_daily_timesnews/}} {{open access}}</ref> occurring on the heels of another winter storm, this snowfall contributed to depths up to {{convert|2|ft|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} at higher elevations.<ref name="ncdc158-159"/> High winds from the storm left at least 50,000 electric customers in the [[Richmond, Virginia]] region without power. In [[Carroll County, Virginia|Carroll County]], strong winds uprooted trees.<ref name="airports"/> Significant snow accumulations occurred throughout the Mid-Atlantic, chiefly away from the coastal plain. Snowfall exceeded {{convert|10|in|cm|abbr=on}} in parts of western [[Virginia]], western [[Maryland]], and [[West Virginia]]; [[Washington, D.C.]] received {{convert|12.1|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow.<ref name="KU467"/>
===Northeast U.S.=== The cyclone was rated by meteorology researchers [[Paul Kocin|Kocin]] and Uccellini (2004) as a high-end Category 3 on the Northeast Snowfall Impact Scale, equating to a "major" winter storm.<ref name="KU467"/> However, more recent data from the [[National Climatic Data Center]] classifies the nor'easter as a low-end "crippling" Category 4.<ref name="NCDC"/> By December 30, at least 20 deaths in New York and New England had been attributed to the storm, largely from traffic accidents and physical exhaustion.<ref name="Albany"/>
Areas of northeastern [[Pennsylvania]], eastern New York, and Vermont received snowfall in excess of {{convert|20|in|cm|abbr=on}}, including {{convert|29.8|in|mm|abbr=on}} at [[Burlington, Vermont|Burlington]], {{convert|26.4|in|cm|abbr=on}} at [[Albany, New York|Albany]], and {{convert|21.9|in|cm|abbr=on}} at [[Binghamton, New York]].<ref name="KU467"/> Accumulations locally exceeded {{convert|40|in|cm|abbr=on}},<ref name="aly"/> with {{convert|45|in|cm|abbr=on}} measured at [[Waitsfield, Vermont]] and {{convert|48|in|cm|abbr=on}} in the small village of [[East Wallingford, Vermont]].<ref name="ncdc159"/><ref name="48in">{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Wintry blast buries much of New England|date=December 29, 1969|newspaper=The El Dorado Times|accessdate=January 10, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4014995/the_el_dorado_times/}} {{open access}}</ref> The storm remains one of the greatest on record in cities like Albany and Burlington, and contributed to high monthly snowfall totals; in Albany, December 1969 stands as the snowiest documented month, with {{convert|57.5|in|cm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="aly"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Burlington, Vermont top 20 greatest snowstorms|publisher=National Weather Service Burlington, Vermont|accessdate=January 10, 2015|url=http://www.weather.gov/media/btv/climo/extremes/top20snow.pdf}}</ref> Throughout the region, the weight of the snow, combined with [[Beaufort scale|gale-force]] winds, collapsed roofs and brought down power lines.<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|title=New England Clogged by 2-Day Snow|date=December 28, 1969|work=The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=January 7, 2011|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/631921492.html?dids=631921492:631921492&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Dec+28%2C+1969&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=NEW+ENGLAND+CLOGGED+BY+2-DAY+SNOW&pqatl=google}}</ref> The winds blew snow from this and previous storms into drifts as high as {{convert|30|ft|m|abbr=on|sigfig=1}},<ref name="Vermont">{{cite web|author=Lesley-Ann Dupigny-Giroux|title=Climate Variability and Socioeconomic Consequences of Vermont's Natural Hazards: A Historical Perspective|year=2002|publisher=Vermont Historical Society|accessdate=January 7, 2010|url=http://www.vthistory.org/journal/70/vt701_204.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725172833/http://www.vthistory.org/journal/70/vt701_204.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-25}}</ref> blocking roads and leaving some communities isolated.<ref name="Albany"/> In some areas, travel was only possible with snowmobiles, which were used by emergency workers to deliver emergency supplies as needed. Rescuers also used snowmobiles and aircraft to search for stranded residents and travelers.<ref name="ncdc159"/><ref name="Albany"/> Many cities and counties throughout the Northeast issued [[snow emergencies]].<ref name="ncdc157"/><ref>{{cite news|author=United Press International|title=Cities declare emergencies: Conn. banks ordered closed|date=December 26, 1969|newspaper=Naugatuck Daily News|accessdate=January 11, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4022897/naugatuck_daily_news/}} {{open access}}</ref> Business and industry suffered extensively in the days following the storm.<ref name="ncdc157">''Storm Data'', p. 157</ref>
While major highways were generally cleared by December 29,<ref name="climo">{{cite book|author=A. Boyd Pack|chapter=New York – December 1969: special weather summary|title=Climatological data. New York, Volumes 80–81|publisher=National Climactic Data Center|accessdate=January 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YbfcO5Y9wioC&pg=RA1-PA210|page=210|year=1968}}</ref> some local roads reportedly remained covered for up to a month.<ref name="aly"/> About {{convert|230|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the [[New York State Thruway]]—nearly half its total length—was closed for 27 hours.<ref>{{cite news|author=United Press International|date=December 26, 1969|newspaper=The Daily Messenger|accessdate=January 11, 2016|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4022932/the_daily_messenger/|title=State-wide storm has caused closing of Thruway|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=United Press International|date=December 29, 1969|title=Storm closes Albany state offices|newspaper=The Daily Messenger|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate=January 11, 2016|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4023053/the_daily_messenger/}}</ref> The snowfall also caused widespread property damage, as the roofs of barns, sheds, and other buildings caved in under the weight of the snow. An airport hangar in [[Oneonta, New York|Oneonta]] collapsed, destroying five aircraft inside. In the aftermath of the storm, many homes sustained water damage from melting snow. "Innumerable" traffic accidents were reported, and many motorists became stranded or were forced to abandon their vehicles.<ref name="ncdc157"/> Four people in a stalled automobile died of [[carbon monoxide poisoning]]. Also in New York, one man froze to death, and three individuals were killed in a building collapse.<ref name="ncdc157"/> In the [[Capital District, New York|Capital District]], the snow fell with a high water content, occasionally mixing with freezing rain. As a result, it was much denser than normal and proved difficult to manage. The City of Albany spent a record $2 million [[USD]] on snow removal,<ref name="aly">{{cite web|author=National Weather Service Albany, New York|title=Major Winter Storms|date=|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=January 10, 2016|url=http://www.weather.gov/aly/MajorWinterStorms}}</ref> and the city restricted nearly all traffic except for vehicles necessary to maintain emergency supplies.<ref name="Albany">{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Northeast Stays Paralyzed By Storm|date=December 30, 1969|work=The Lewiston Morning Tribune|accessdate=January 7, 2011|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AZJfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7TAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3083,5879267&dq=snow+albany&hl=en}}</ref> Governor [[Nelson Rockefeller]] closed state offices in Albany on December 29 and 30, in an effort to enable efficient snow removal.<ref>{{cite news|author=Charles Dumas|title=Storm extends state government holiday to five days|date=December 30, 1969|newspaper=The Oneonta Star|accessdate=January 11, 2016|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4023009/the_oneonta_star/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Mayor [[Erastus Corning 2nd]] assessed the situation as a "dire emergency".<ref>{{cite news|author=Bill Kovachs|title=Albany Calls 'Dire' Emergency As 26-Inch Snow Paralyzes Area; Albany Declares 'Dire Emergency' After 26-Inch Snowstorm|date=December 30, 1969|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 7, 2011|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0F17FF38581B7493C2AA1789D95F4D8685F9}}</ref>
[[File:Nor'easter 1969-12-27 weather map.jpg|thumb|Map of the nor'easter on December 27 over eastern New England]]
Governor [[Deane C. Davis]] of Vermont declared a state of emergency and ordered the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] to assist with cleanup efforts.<ref name="Modesto">{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=4-Foot Snow, Flood Strangle Northeast|date=December 29, 1969|work=The Modesto Bee}}</ref> Blowing snow continuously blocked roads after being cleared, and snow removal vehicles, not equipped to withstand the excessive snow, began experiencing mechanical issues. The storm left some communities without power or telephone service for up to two days, although isolated outages persisted longer.<ref name="Albany"/> One person died in [[Saxtons River, Vermont|Saxtons River]].<ref name="ncdc159"/> With roads impassable in both New York and New England, tank trucks could not reach dairy farmers, who were in some cases forced to discard thousands of gallons of milk.<ref name="ncdc157">''Storm Data'', p. 157</ref><ref name="Vermont"/> In other cases, power outages rendered equipment useless, requiring milking to be done manually.<ref name="Albany"/> One person in New Hampshire died of exhaustion during the storm.<ref name="ncdc157">''Storm Data'', p. 157</ref>
The influx of warm, moist air over a wedge of cold air near the surface resulted in a severe ice storm across central and northern New England, most notably in the upper [[Connecticut River|Connecticut River Valley]]. [[Glaze ice]] thicker than {{convert|2|in|mm|abbr=on}}, and reportedly up to {{convert|6|in|mm|abbr=on}} thick in Vermont, built up on trees and power lines, wreaking "unbelievable" havoc.<ref name="ncdc159"/> In the hardest-hit areas, damage from the ice storm was comparable to that caused by the [[1938 New England hurricane]].<ref name="ncdc157"/> The combined load of snow and ice caused significant damage to many residential and industrial buildings, with several factory and warehouse roofs collapsing.<ref name="ncdc159"/><ref name="ice"/> Livestock were killed in multiple rural building collapses throughout the area.<ref name="ncdc159"/> Southern Maine endured its second damaging ice storm in a week, with many of the same communities losing power on both occasion.<ref name="ncdc156"/> Precipitation also transitioned to freezing rain and sleet across interior [[Connecticut]], where the dangerous conditions induced numerous traffic accidents.<ref name="ncdc154">''Storm Data'', p. 154</ref> Due to the abnormally cold temperatures in the wake of the storm, the glaze persisted for up to six weeks, much longer than the typical three days for ice storms in New England.<ref name="ice">{{cite journal|author=S. F. Ackley and K. Itagaki|title=Distribution of Icing in the Northeast's Ice Storm of 26–27 December 1969|date=1970|journal=Weatherwise|volume=23|issue=6|pages=274|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00431672.1970.9932909?tab=permissions|accessdate=January 9, 2016|doi=10.1080/00431672.1970.9932909}}</ref>
The changeover to heavy rain in southern and eastern New England swelled frozen rivers, creating ice jams which induced severe flooding. Flooding of roadways and homes was compounded by drainage issues from the dense snowcover.<ref name="ncdc156"/> Rising floodwaters forced hundreds of families to leave their homes in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Maine. Up to {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain fell in the [[Boston]] region, where thousands of homes were inundated. Rivers had begun to recede by December 29 after cresting well above flood stage.<ref name="Modesto"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|title=Vermont Declared a Disaster Area|date=December 29, 1969|work=The Meriden Journal|accessdate=January 7, 2011|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rcZHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PP8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=803,8248600&dq=vermont+ice-storm&hl=en}}</ref> Up to {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain fell over [[Rhode Island]] after {{convert|6|to|11|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow, with widespread flooding reported in multiple towns. Frequent automobile accidents and large traffic jams were reported in the state.<ref name="ncdc159">''Storm Data'', p. 159</ref> Winds were strongest in [[Cape Cod|Cape Cod, Massachusetts]], where gusts peaked near {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The gales were particularly damaging to trees laden with snow and ice. The heavy rainfall in eastern Massachusetts added tremendous weigh to the snow that had already fallen, causing roof collapses and making it difficult to clear the snow. In southeastern New Hampshire, the strong winds toppled trees and blew out windows in [[Hampton Beach, New Hampshire|Hampton Beach]].<ref name="ncdc157"/> Although the coastal plain of New England avoided the heaviest snow accumulations, pounding surf and strong winds battered piers, boats, and other coastal installations, while low-lying areas experienced [[storm surge]] flooding.<ref name="ncdc156-157">''Storm Data'', pp. 156–157</ref>
===Quebec=== The storm dropped up to {{convert|30|in|cm|abbr=on|round=5}} of snow in southern [[Quebec]], where wind gusts up to {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} damaged buildings and brought down power lines.<ref name="press"/> Over a period of 60 hours, {{convert|27.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow fell at [[Montreal]] in what was then the city's heaviest snowfall on record. Rail, air, and automobile transportation were paralyzed.<ref name="quebec">{{cite journal|author=Mark E. H. Trueman|title=Montreal's great snowstorm of ′69|date=1970|volume=23|issue=6|pages=270|journal=[[Weatherwise]]|accessdate=January 9, 2016|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00431672.1970.9932908?journalCode=vwws20|doi=10.1080/00431672.1970.9932908}}</ref> One individual in [[Quebec City]] was struck and killed by a snowplow, and two more died of exposure to cold while [[ice fishing]] on the [[St. Lawrence River]]. Several fires broke out in Montreal during the storm, killing at least six people and leaving 23 families homeless.<ref name="press">{{cite news|author=The Canadian Press|title=Death, destruction in Quebec blizzard|date=December 29, 1969|newspaper=The Brandon Sun|accessdate=January 9, 2016|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4001309/the_brandon_sun/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> In total, the storm was connected to at least 15 fatalities in the province.<ref name="quebec"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Climat-Quebec|title=Significant Climate Events of the 20th Century in Québec|publisher=Meteorological Service of Canada|accessdate=January 9, 2016|url=http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p24&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151128014516/http://www.climat-quebec.qc.ca/home.php?id=p24&mpn=ev_mto_sig&lg=en|archivedate=November 28, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

'''<big>Ecosystem respiration</big>''' <small>is the operation in which the organisms within a specified ecosystem use the process of respiration to convert organic carbon to carbon dioxide. While the amount of respiration is varied upon the type of ecosystem and the community abundance, the mechanism occurs in both aquatic and terrestrial environments.</small>
'''Ecosystem respiration''' is the sum of all [[cellular respiration|respiration]] occurring by the living organisms in a specific [[ecosystem]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yvon-Durocher|first=Gabriel|last2=Caffrey|first2=Jane M.|last3=Cescatti|first3=Alessandro|last4=Dossena|first4=Matteo|last5=Giorgio|first5=Paul del|last6=Gasol|first6=Josep M.|last7=Montoya|first7=José M.|last8=Pumpanen|first8=Jukka|last9=Staehr|first9=Peter A.|date=2012-06-20|title=Reconciling the temperature dependence of respiration across timescales and ecosystem types|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature11205|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=487|issue=7408|pages=472–476|doi=10.1038/nature11205|issn=0028-0836}}</ref>
Ecosystem respiration is typically measured in the natural environment, such as a forest or grassland field, rather than in the laboratory. Ecosystem respiration is the production portion of [[carbon dioxide]] in an ecosystem's [[carbon flux]], while [[photosynthesis]] typically accounts for the majority of the ecosystem's carbon consumption.
'''<big>How ecosystem respiration works and its importance:</big>'''
<small>Ecosystem respiration happens when a cell takes glucose and oxygen and uses it to produce carbon dioxide, energy, and water. This transaction is important not only for the benefit of the cells, but for the carbon dioxide output provided, which is key in the process of photosynthesis. Without respiration, actions necessary to life, such as metabolic processes and photosynthesis, would cease</small>

Turekian. 702 pp. Elsevier, 2005. {{ISBN|0-08-044642-6}} *Yvon-Durocher, Gabriel; Caffrey, Jane M.; Cescatti, Alessandro; Dossena, Matteo; Giorgio, Paul del; Gasol, Josep M.; Montoya, José M.; Pumpanen, Jukka; Staehr, Peter A.
